As real as social emotional needs get. #LoveWorks

1106319276405719040.text: So much wisdom in this article: I’ve been thinking a lot about how Grimm fairytales serve a purpose. The Inuit teach kids lessons with storytelling instead of yelling at them. Perhaps we should tell more ‘scary’ stories and discipline less?

1106318984809349120.text: ‘Why don’t you hit me?’ My mother has Cree ancestry and did this: while we were on a swing she had us ‘kick’ her in the back. She would come up and act shocked that we could do such a thing. It was hysterical but now I realize it also taught us not to hit without discipline.

1106307147439067137.text:
Inuit advice: Even if a child hits you or bites you, there's no raising your voice?
"No, with little kids, you often think they're pushing your buttons, but that's not what's going on. They're upset about something, and you have to figure out what it is."https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2019/03/13/685533353/a-playful-way-to-teach-kids-to-control-their-anger …

1093553904527110144.text: I have never seen anyone use ND PAE even when there are high levels of confirmed alcohol and drug exposure in utero. If we don’t diagnose it then we don’t set aside funds for prevention. https://www.theravive.com/therapedia/neurobehavioral-disorder-associated-with-prenatal-alcohol-exposure-dsm--5 …

1093282530512388096.text: Viewing traumatic responses as ‘Oppositional Defiant Disorder’ pathologizes survival skills. We should not be suppressing kids who say no instead we should work on building trust and agency to encourage engagement. Saying no is an important skill to prevent further abuse.

1093261001170989056.text: So many other diagnosis make sense and don’t cause others to view this as bad behavior: Depression, Adjustment disorder, PTSD etc. Let’s stop using Conduct Disorder and ODD for kids with complex trauma. Thoughts?

1093259284815597568.text: Diagnosing a child who has experienced trauma, abuse and multiple foster home placements with Conduct Disorder is like diagnosing an adult who was on 10 red eye flights in a row and then robbed with bipolar disorder. It’s the situation not the child. Why are we still doing this?

1070867383680552962.text: True! But let’s talk about it! Just means we need to put the data about how a child learns in context. So many parents come to me confused about what is going on. Dyslexia gives them an explanation that allows them to stop blaming themselves. Then we plan interventions.

1070473277661835264.text: As school psychs, we need to start using the term #dyslexia.  Parents can get lost in the jargon of 'a Specific Learning Disability with Auditory Processing deficits.'  It's easy and empowering for kids to say 'I have trouble reading because I have dyslexia.'

1069291639498203137.text: Love this list! As adults we can support children in identifying helpful coping strategies, allow them to chose when to use those strategies, celebrate healthy choices, and above all respond to their requests for connection. Even if you are busy  just saying ‘I see you’ can help.https://twitter.com/CenterOnTrauma/status/1068620222213574658 …

1068014263589949440.text: We must start adapting our classrooms to meet the needs of children. Not manipulating children to meet the needs of school. Youngest Children In A Class Are Most Likely To Get ADHD Diagnosis -https://www.npr.org/671614909

1064945863313678336.text: Happy Thanksgiving! Holidays bring people together to celebrate but they can also be triggering. One strategy: model how to contact the crisis line. 1064567547247259649.text: 'Everything in moderation' my father used to say. Turns out this is true for executive functioning as well. Why does the frontal lobe develop last? 1036383171896463360.text: This is the future of education, we do not need more testing which leads to more interventions and band aid accommodations. We need environments that identify the strengths of children, encourage their curiosity, and adapt accordingly.pic.twitter.com/0LtOQzIeNX

1033003765110992896.text: Heard from concerned parents who find out at the start of school their child lacks expected skills. We need an educational system that focuses on competencies (what kids can do) and is transparent. Grades and test scores give parents a fragmented and unclear view of learning.

1027934242792124416.text: A teacher asked me what to say when a child reports their parent is in jail.
